contentrichtext.text: {{Distinguish2|''xview'', an alias for the ''xloadimage'' [[image viewer]]}} [[Image:xview-calctool.png|thumb|right|200px|SunOS XView calctool]] '''XView''' is a [[widget toolkit]] from [[Sun Microsystems]] introduced in 1988. It provides an [[OPEN LOOK]] user interface for [[X Window System]] applications, with an object-oriented [[application programming interface]] (API) for the [[C (programming language)|C programming language]]. Its interface, controls, and layouts are very close to that of the earlier [[SunView]] window system, making it easy to convert existing applications from SunView to X. Sun also produced the [[User Interface Toolkit]] (UIT), a [[C++]] API to XView. The XView source code has been freely available since the early 1990s, making it the "first [[open-source]] professional-quality X Window System toolkit".<ref name="darwin">{{cite web |url = http://www.darwinsys.com/history/ |title = Ian Darwin: Computing History, Myths and Legends |accessdate = 2008-06-15 |author = Ian Darwin |date = }}</ref> XView was later abandoned by Sun in favor of [[Motif (widget toolkit)|Motif]] (the basis of [[Common Desktop Environment|CDE]]), and more recently [[GTK+]] (the basis of [[GNOME]]). XView was reputedly the first system to use right-button [[context menu]]s,<ref name="darwin"/> which are now ubiquitous among computer user interfaces. == See also == * [[OLIT]] * [[MoOLIT]] * [[OpenWindows]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{FOLDOC}} == Further reading == * Dan Heller, ''XView Programming Manual'' (O'Reilly & Associates, 1991) ISBN 0-937175-87-0 [ftp://ftp.ora.com/pub/openlook/vol7a.pdf Volume 7] * Thomas Van Raalte, ed.
